titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Elaine Marie de Kooning papers, circa 1959-1988, in the Archives of American Art AAA.dekoelas
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Harriet E. Shapiro

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 239307

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-07-30T15:49-0400

did.unittitle: Elaine Marie de Kooning papers
did.abstract: The Elaine Marie de Kooning papers are dated circa 1959-1988 and measure 0.7 linear feet. Two scrapbooks contain printed material, letters, and photographs that document de Kooning's protest against the death penalty and efforts to save the life of convicted criminal Caryl Chessman. There are 13 transcripts of interviews of Elaine de Kooning, conversations between de Kooning and others, and lectures by de Kooning. Also found are photographs, clippings, and 2 wooden Easter eggs sent by the White House to de Kooning to be decorated and returned. There is also an unprocessed addition that includes letters and postcards, subject files relating to de Kooning's portrait of president John F. Kennedy, photographs of de Kooning and others, additional writings, and a home recording sound disc of Willem de Kooning whistling.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the Archives of American Art in 2003 by Denise Lassaw, de Kooning's goddaughter and her mother Ernestine Lassaw, and in 2013-2015 by Denise Lassaw. Interview transcripts and lectures were donated in 2015 by Doris Aach, an artist who transcribed them for de Kooning.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Harriet E. Shapiro in 2013.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Elaine Marie de Kooning papers, circa 1959-1988. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original materials requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Elaine Marie de Kooning papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Elaine de Kooning (1918-1989) was an Abstract Expressionist painter, teacher and writer who lived and worked in New York City and East Hampton, N.Y.

Born in Brooklyn, New York, de Kooning studied briefly at Hunter College before enrolling at the Leonardo da Vinci Art School in New York City. She had her first solo exhibition in 1952 at the Stable Gallery in New York and has paintings in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and other institutions. She taught at Yale University, Carnegie Mellon Institute, University of Pennsylvania and other colleges and art schools. Elaine de Kooning died of lung cancer in 1989 at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, New York. Willem de Kooning, her husband of 48 years, survived her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Elaine Marie de Kooning papers are dated circa 1959-1988 and measure 0.7 linear feet. Two scrapbooks contain printed material, letters, and photographs that document de Kooning's protest against the death penalty and efforts to save the life of convicted criminal Caryl Chessman. There are 13 transcripts of interviews of Elaine de Kooning, conversations between de Kooning and others, and lectures by de Kooning. Also found are photographs, clippings, and 2 wooden Easter eggs sent by the White House to de Kooning to be decorated and returned.

An unprocessed addition includes includes letters and postcards to Elaine de Kooning, subject files relating to de Kooning's portrait of president John F. Kennedy, a price list of drawings, photographs of de Kooning and others, additional writings and photocopies of letters about Willem de Kooning by Mercedes Matter, Ernestine Lawson and others, published serigraphs from the California Institute of Arts, and a. Also included is a home recording sound disc of Willem de Kooning whistling.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 2 series:

list.item: Series 2: Interviews, Conversations, and Lectures, 1978-1988 (Box 1; 0.3 linear feet)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Among the holding of the Archives is an oral history interview conducted in 1981 by Phyllis Tuchman, for the Archives of American Art's Mark Rothko and His Times oral history project. Also found is a collection of Elaine and Willem de Kooning financial records.

did.unittitle: Scrapbooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two scrapbooks, compiled by Elaine de Kooning, pertain to her effort to save the life of convicted criminal, Caryl Chessman, and her protest against the death penalty. Volume 1 "The Chessman Story" contains clippings. Volume 2 includes a copy of Chessman's 16 page letter to Governor Edmund G. Brown, clippings concerning efforts to save Chessman, de Kooning's speech notes for political rallies, her correspondence with attorney Rosalie Asher, and photographs of members of the art community involved with this cause.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook, Volume 1, "The Chessman Story"
Scrapbook, Volume 2
Interviews, Conversations, and Lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are 13 transcripts of audio interviews of Elaine de Kooning; conversations between de Kooning and others; and lectures by de Kooning (also included is a CD containing Word files of the transcripts and a jpeg of a note to Doris Aach from Elaine de Kooning concerning her “first piece of sculpture,” and a jpeg of that sculpture). The interviews, conversations, and lectures were transcribed by Doris Aach for Elaine de Kooning, who planned to use them for a book.

did.unittitle: CD

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: CD contains Word files of the printed transcripts, a jpeg note to Doris Aach from Elaine de Kooning concerning her "first piece of sculpture"; and a second jpeg image of that sculpture.
